Brevibacterium iodinum is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Brevibacterium. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile rod-shaped bacterium. Brevibacterium iodinum is known for its ability to produce a distinctive violet or purple pigment, which is believed to be a result of the accumulation of iodine-containing compounds within the bacterial cells.

This species is commonly found in various environmental sources, such as soil, water, and dairy products. It is considered a halotolerant bacterium, meaning it can grow in the presence of moderate concentrations of salt. Brevibacterium iodinum is known to be involved in the biodegradation of certain organic compounds and may play a role in the cycling of iodine in the environment.

Due to its unique pigment production and potential biotechnological applications, Brevibacterium iodinum has been the subject of various research studies, particularly in the fields of microbiology, biotechnology, and environmental science.
